facts.text: Respondent sold trees of spontaneous growth in its estate for Rs. 50,000 during the assessment year 1963-64

anchor.surface_text: The respondent sold trees of spontaneous growth in its estate for Rs. 50,000 during the assessment year 1963-64.

facts.text: Assessing authority levied sales tax by treating the amount as taxable turnover under the Act

anchor.surface_text: The assessing authority levied sales tax by treating the aforesaid amount as taxable turnover under the Act.

facts.text: Appellate Assistant Commissioner confirmed the order of assessing authority

anchor.surface_text: In appeal the Appellate Assistant Commissioner companyfirmed that order.

facts.text: Appellant filed petition before High Court raising questions of law

anchor.surface_text: The appellant herein filed a petition before the High Court raising the following questions of law

facts.text: Trees of spontaneous growth cannot be regarded as produced by agriculture or horticulture

anchor.surface_text: Such trees which have grown spontaneously and without any plantation by that person cannot possibly be regarded as having been produced by him by agriculture or horticulture.

facts.text: Cutting of trees done by the contractor

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in the present case has number been found to have done anything towards the production of the trees and even the cutting has been done by the companytractor.

facts.text: Respondent owns and maintains private forest

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, a person owning and maintaining private forest and selling trees of spontaneous growth therein, is a dealer

facts.text: No appearance on behalf of the respondent

anchor.surface_text: R. Krishna Pillai, for the appellant. The respondent did number appear.
The Judgment of the Court was delivered by Grover, J.
Appeal by special leave from the order dated September 15, 1966 of the Kerala High Court in Tax Revision Case No. 106 of 1966.
This is an appeal by special leave from a judgment
the respondent companypany was number a dealer within the meaning of s. 2 viii  of the Kerala General Sales Tax Act 1963  Act 15 of 1963  hereinafter called the Act.

anchor.surface_text: According to that definition dealer means any person who carried on the business of buying, selling, supplying or distributing goods directly or otherwise whether for cash or for deferred payment or for companymission, remuneration or other valuable companysideration and includes  e  a person who sells goods produced by him by manufacture, agriculture, horticulture or otherwise.

issues.text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, a person owning and maintaining private forest and selling trees of spontaneous growth therein, is a dealer within the meaning of section 2 viii  of the Kerala General Sales Tax Act, 1963 ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether on the facts and in the circumstances of this case, a person owning and maintaining private forest and selling trees of spontaneous growth therein, is a dealer within the meaning of section 2 viii  of the Kerala General Sales Tax Act,

issues.text: Whether such a person is liable to the levy of sales-tax respect of sales of his timber, under the said Act ?

anchor.surface_text: Whether such a person is liable to the levy of sales-tax respect of sales of his timber, under the said Act ? As mentioned before the High Court rejected the petition for revision at the preliminary hearing.

issues.text: whether on the findings given by the Appellate Tribunal the respondent can be regarded as a dealer within the definition given in s. 2 viii

anchor.surface_text: The sole question is whether on the findings given by the Appellate Tribunal the respondent can be regarded as a dealer within the definition given in s. 2 viii . According to that definition dealer means any person who carried on the busine

issues.text: whether maintenance of a private forest with a view to producing and selling valuable timber with the usual attributes of business present in the said activity, namely, periodicity, continuity and profit motive would amount to such process

anchor.surface_text: the basic question it is said, was whether maintenance of a private forest with a view to producing and selling valuable timber with the usual attributes of business present in the said activity, namely, periodicity, continuity and profit mot

issues.text: whether the said activity i.e., forestry would number come within the scope of agriculture, horticulture or otherwise particularly when the respondent owns substantial area of forest land, and timber from the trees of spontaneous growth is sold year after year with the object of earning profit

anchor.surface_text: The other question as whether the said activity i.e., forestry would number come within the scope of agriculture, horticulture or otherwise particularly when the respondent owns substantial area of forest land, and timber from the trees of spontaneous growth is sold year after year with the object of earning profit.

arguments.claim: Under the contract, by the process of uprooting the trees, the respondent produced timber and is covered by the definition of a dealer in s. 2(viii)

anchor.surface_text: The Tribunal did not accede to the contention of the State representative that under the contract, by the process of uprooting the trees, the respondent produced timber

arguments.court_reasoning: Uprooting not done by respondent and no process employed to produce timber

arguments.claim: Uprooting of trees not done by respondent and no process employed by which timber produced by it, hence not a dealer under s. 2(viii)

anchor.surface_text: and no process had been employed by which it could be said that timber had been produced by it.

arguments.court_reasoning: Spontaneous growth lacks production; requires volition and effort; respondent did no production or cutting

arguments.claim: Appellate Tribunal erred in assuming any agricultural, horticultural or other process was involved in producing the timber sold

anchor.surface_text: It has been contended before us by learned counsel for the appellant that the Appellate Tribunal erred in assuming that any agricultural, horticultural or other process was involved in producing the timber sold.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ificant and cannot be lost sight of. The intention in employing the word produced obviously was to introduce an element of volition and effort involvi

arguments.court_reasoning: Production requires bringing into existence with volition/effort; spontaneous trees lack this

arguments.claim: Maintenance of private forest to produce and sell timber with periodicity, continuity, profit motive amounts to production process under s. 2(viii)

anchor.surface_text: The basic question it is said, was whether maintenance of a private forest with a view to producing and selling valuable timber with the usual attributes of business present in the said activity, namely, periodicity, continuity and profit motive would amount to such process.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ificant and cannot be lost sight of. The intention in employing the word produced obviously was to introduce an element of volition and effort involvi

arguments.court_reasoning: Element of production absent in spontaneous growth; requires volition/effort/process

arguments.claim: Forestry activity comes within agriculture, horticulture or otherwise, especially with substantial land and yearly sales for profit

anchor.surface_text: The other question as whether the said activity i.e., forestry would come within the scope of agriculture, horticulture or otherwise particularly when the respondent owns substantial area of forest land, and timber from the trees of spontaneous growth is sold year after year with the object of earning profit.

court_response_anchor.surface_text: ion it is said, was whether maintenance of a private forest with a view to producing and selling valuable timber with the usual attributes of business

arguments.court_reasoning: Spontaneous trees not produced by agriculture/horticulture; 'otherwise' requires production element

arguments.claim: Trees of spontaneous growth without plantation cannot be regarded as produced by agriculture or horticulture

anchor.surface_text: Such trees which have grown spontaneously and without any plantation by that person cannot possibly be regarded as having been produced by him by agriculture or horticulture.

arguments.claim: 'Otherwise' cannot cover spontaneous trees as element of production must be present; 'produce' means bring into existence from raw materials with effort

anchor.surface_text: The word otherwise also cannot cover trees of spontaneous growth since the element of production must be present. The context in which the word produced appears in the definition can only mean to bring forth, bring into being or existence-to bring a thing into existence from its raw materials or elements

arguments.claim: Juxtaposition of 'manufacture' with agriculture/horticulture indicates intention for volition and effort in production

anchor.surface_text: The juxtaposition of the word manufacture with agriculture and horticulture is significant and cannot be lost sight of. The intention in employing the word produced obviously was to introduce an element of volition and effort involving the employment of some process

arguments.claim: Respondent did nothing towards production of trees; even cutting done by contractor, hence not selling goods produced by it

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in the present case has not been found to have done anything towards the production of the trees and even the cutting has been done by the contractor.

holdings.text: Such trees which have grown spontaneously and without any plantation by that person cannot possibly be regarded as having been produced by him by agriculture or horticulture.

anchor.surface_text: Such trees which have grown spontaneously and without any plantation by that person cannot possibly be regarded as having been produced by him by agriculture or horticulture.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Spontaneous growth without human intervention like plantation excludes classification as produced by agriculture or horticulture.

holdings.text: The word otherwise also cannot cover trees of spontaneous growth since the element of production must be present.

anchor.surface_text: The word otherwise also cannot cover trees of spontaneous growth since the element of production must be present. The context in which the word produced appears in the definition can only mean to bring forth, bring into being or existence-to bring

holdings.reasoning_summary: All categories in the definition require an element of production, which is absent in spontaneous growth.

holdings.text: The context in which the word produced appears in the definition can only mean to bring forth, bring into being or existence-to bring a thing into existence from its raw materials or elements.

anchor.surface_text: The context in which the word produced appears in the definition can only mean to bring forth, bring into being or existence-to bring a thing into existence from its raw materials or elements See the meaning of the word ,produce- in the Shorter Oxford English Dictionary . According to Websters International English Dictionary the verb produce means to bring forward, beget etc.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Relies on dictionary definitions to ascertain ordinary meaning of 'produced' as requiring transformation from raw materials.

holdings.text: The juxtaposition of the word manufacture with agriculture and horticulture is significant and cannot be lost sight of. The intention in employing the word produced obviously was to introduce an element of volition and effort involving the employment of some process for bringing into existence the goods.

anchor.surface_text: The juxtaposition of the word manufacture with agriculture and horticulture is significant and cannot be lost sight of. The intention in employing the word produced obviously was to introduce an element of volition and effort involving the employment of some process

holdings.reasoning_summary: Contextual reading of associated terms indicates legislative intent for active human involvement in production.

holdings.text: The respondent in the present case has not been found to have done anything towards the production of the trees and even the cutting has been done by the contractor.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent in the present case has number been found to have done anything towards the production of the trees and even the cutting has been done by the companytractor.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Accepts tribunal findings that no production process was employed by respondent, including no uprooting or cutting.

holdings.text: The respondent therefore cannot possibly be regarded as a person who sells goods produced by him by agriculture, horticulture or otherwise.

anchor.surface_text: The respondent therefore cannot possibly be regarded as a person who sells goods produced by him by agriculture, horticulture or otherwise. On the above view of the matter the appeal fails and is dis- missed.

holdings.reasoning_summary: Integrates statutory interpretation of 'produced' with undisputed facts to conclude respondent outside dealer definition.
